subject: RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy
msgSnippet: ... I hope that you don t feel that everyone s contentious, there is a spirit of the free exchange of ideas.  (I m referring to your previous post.)  By the
messageBody:
On Wed, 2003-07-30 at 21:08, Adam Jack wrote:
> David wrote:
>
> Here is the crux of the problem with your argument. As far as I
> understand unit testing using an xUnit framework and as part of the XP
> process. The existence of test interdependencies (outside of thread
> testing) is a code smell which is avoided. If the xUnit framework
> were
> to support the concept of dependencies it would be promoting a
> specific
> code smell which it is intende to avoid.
>
> I don't think a truer word has been spoken in this thread. I think you are
> spot on. I think I trod in some "test *content* dependency" stigma, when I
> was discussing run order "test dependency order", which I don't feel is the
> same.

I hope that you don't feel that everyone's contentious, there is a
spirit of the free exchange of ideas. (I'm referring to your previous
post.) By the way what language are you working in?

>
> I am not saying my tests depends upon the run of another, no side effects, I
> am saying "if my fruit class fails why bother testing my apple class? It has
> a rotten core." It kinda goes back to Bertrand Russell... If I know fruit is
> bad, then the fact that apple succeeds doesn't make it a healthy apple, it
> is unknown.
>

The way I understand this type of situation with testing in XP.

1. I only test one or two classes relative to the one I'm currently
working on. Periodically (rarely) I run all tests. A little more often
I will run a suite that's a little bigger, specific to my module.

2. I only test functionality at it's source. Meaning that subclasses
don't test inherited behavior.

Is this what you're referring to? Inherited behavior? I tend to only
run tests on the code I'm working on. Before I start working I run all
tests. I run all tests when I pull updates from CVS into my source
tree. And I run all tests when I'm done making code changes before I
check my code in. But I don't run all the tests all the time. I hear
what you're saying, however I can't see it coming up for me during real
development cycles.



> Still, I don't think the idea has a chance of a fair hearing.

Well, ask Ron Jeffries or Kent Beck directly what they think. Provide
an example in code. We may be missing something, it does happen. I
don't think any of us is fool enough to think we aren't.

> I agree in principle. That said, I tests in layers, building on each other.
> I can't put 1000 tests in one testcase, just as I would put 1000 class in
> one package. I just wanted to bring run order through simple statements of
> dependency. I think you see what I was saying, and you've explained why I am
> getting nowhere.

When we talk about testing here, are you talking about Unit Testing as a
tool to write code? Or are you talking about QA and/or Acceptance
Testing?

> Point taken on discouragement, and boy -- yes -- I've felt that. ;-)

Hehe, it's not personal.

> I think test content dependency is wrong, but not what I am saying. Either
> that, or you decouple yourself from everything you do, a purist goal of no
> real world value. Code used code, that is a dependency.

Now, this decoupling point is I think the key. I think you'd find some
really healthy discussion about decoupling here. Decoupling is to me
the holy grail for healthy code. And these people prove daily that unit
testing helps get you there.


> This is all about test content dependency -- side effects -- and I never
> meant that. Why get a fruit basket full of errors when fruit is bad? I was
> actually trying to reduce this mess of an output to "the *possible* root
> cause -- and if nothing else, a place to start cleaning up".

Oh this is what you want... Well, that may be a reasonable thing.

Are all of your test running everynight? Are all other tests working at
all times other than the one you're working on? They should be. Are
all tests working before you begin coding? Do you break and fix you're
tests repeatedly?

Cheers,

David B
